unit.alt: Logo: 24 hours no-nonsense in groovy Helsinki
Illustration: City of Helsinki coat of arms

gemBase.unit: Pohjoisesplanadi 19, P.O. Box 28, FI-00099 City of Helsinki
By day a relaxing cafe, by night a place to listen to music by local DJs.
The hel-looks website immortalises Helsinki's unique and colourful street fashion.
Enjoy lunch or dinner at this popular local restaurant in the Punavuori district.
You can also observe the local life while enjoying a glass of wine or cup of coffee.
In summertime you can sit outdoors in the square.
A maritime safari by inflatable boat to the historic Söderskär lighthouse is a unique nature experience.
The Eläintarha Skateboard Park features several tracks for trick series and a concrete pool.

The urban park area in the centre of Helsinki is great for jogging, and in summertime you can hire a rowing boat or a pedal boat at the boat rental located on the shore of the Finlandia Hall or visit the cafe at the Blue Villa, Linnunlauluntie 11.
The Cable Factory is Finland's largest cultural centre. "Kaapeli" as it is fondly known hosts exhibitions, fairs, gala evenings, conferences and many other events.

unit.unit: It also houses the Restaurant Hima
& Sali, the Theatre Museum and the Finnish Museum of Photography.

gemBase.unit: Soak up the heat on the smooth granite and take a dip in the refreshing sea.
Pihlajasaari Island also has its own nudist beach.
Ferries depart regularly in summer from the Merisatama Pier near Kaivopuisto Park and from Ruoholahti.
The new Helsinki Ice Park in the Railway Station Square is a popular place to skate in the heart of the city in winter.
Kasino A4 is a Finnish fashion and lifestyle magazine published in English.
It is available from a number of outlets, including the Stockmann Department Store, Academic Bookstore, Design Forum Shop and Museum of Contemporary Art Kiasma.
Viiskulma, the "Five Corners" in the Punavuori district, has become famous for its record shops.
This is a great place to find rare vinyls to bring home with you!
You can also pop into the shops and ask for tips about gigs and nightlife.
Stop into the Stupido-Shop and ask the friendly staff about new Finnish artists or the city's musical offerings.
A record company operates in the same premises.
Wunder is a dream for trend-conscious youths.
In addition to products by Finnish designers, the boutique sells the newest European brands.
You can also find vinyls here.
Myymälä2 is a boutique and gallery in one where you can buy creations by young designers and admire the works of young artists.
Bisquit Satsh is another boutique and gallery that promotes hip-hop street culture.
Hundpark is a boutique that was founded by young designers to promote their own creations.
You won't find these products back home - at least not yet!
Beamhill's two boutiques are situated within seeing distance of each other.
The Mikonkatu shop sells "street style", while Yliopistonkatu street sells Finnish and international designer clothing.
Lux Shop sells youthful and fresh design from both Finland and abroad.
Finnish "streetwear" brands CTRL and Melodica emerged from the skateboarding subculture to become successful consumer brands with street credibility.
The Arla public sauna was cleaning Helsinki residents all the way back in 1929.
The sauna culture has recently been revived at Arla thanks to an enthusiastic landlord.
Erottaja Bar is a favourite hangout for the city's trendliest people, including musicians, designers, architects - everyone comes here!
DJs play the freshest new music at night.
Soul Kitchen offers soul food and drinks in a laid-back atmosphere.
In addition to international dishes, the menu also features traditional Finnish foods.
This retro cafe-bar is favoured by young people in the Kallio district.
The refreshingly messy Beetroot bar charms visitors with its down to earth appeal.
The redbrick walls and old sofas make for a comfortable setting in which to enjoy your drinks.
Relax and enjoy a tasty yet inexpensive lunch or dinner, or just grab a drink and listen to the talk of the town.
Belly serves lunch and drinks in the evenings.
The popular Club Pharaoh plays ska music, and Radio Helsinki, considered by many to be the city's best radio station, has its club evenings here.
DTM is the biggest gay cafe, disco and nightclub in the entire Nordic region.
The "Sixth Line" has rapidly become one of Helsinki's most popular venues for live and club music - highly recommended if you are looking for the newest trends.
Hämeentie 13, entrance from the inner yard (Kaikukatu 4), www.kuudeslinja.com
Lost & Found makes up for its lack of fancy music or decoration with the quality of its staff and customers, making it an extremely popular place for late night drinks every night of the week.
Tavastia is a legendary venue for top Finnish and international bands.
The smaller Semifinal presents up-and-coming stars.
"Beef" is a favourite hangout for young adults in the city centre, attracting extremely trendy partiers especially on weekends.
Hotel Helka's fresh look was inspired by Alvar Aalto and Finnish nature.
Mama's is a favourite place for night food, serving pizza and kebabs every day of the week until five in the morning.
The excellent location of this hostel will save you both time and money in the early hours of the morning.
